title: Replace your VPN
description: Give users secure, auditable network and application access.
detailed_description: This tutorial will show you how to use a combination of Cloudflare products to address use cases typically served by a VPN. Cloudflare provides discrete, Zero Trust enabled application and service access to all TCP and UDP ports in both on-premise and cloud networks. We do this using a combination of an endpoint agent and a network connector, but no other software and no hardware is required for this deployment and security policy is enforced at the Cloudflare edge and managed in your dashboard.

elements.title: Concepts
elements.description:
Concepts explain the basic ideas behind how Cloudflare Zero Trust works.

Feel free to skip if you have a technical background.

pages.link_title: What is a Secure Web Gateway?

elements.title: Review prerequisites
elements.description:
Make sure that you have the following:

  1. A device that can run WARP, our endpoint agent.
  2. A private network with applications or services that are available locally or via a VPN.
  3. A host server that can run the lightweight Cloudflare Tunnel daemon process (requirements).
  4. The ability for that host server to connect to the Internet on the required ports and to connect locally to the private network applications.

pages.additional_description: Once you have finished this step, ask your Cloudflare contact to set up your account as a multi-user organization.

pages.link_title: (Optional) Add public domains and subdomains to Cloudflare
pages.additional_description: You will use these domains to test agentless access to web services. Alternatively, you could purchase a new testing domain through Cloudflare Registrar.

pages.link_title: Create Team Name and Team Domain
pages.additional_description: These values will act as your application portal and authorization realm. For more details, refer to Team Name.

elements.title: Connect private network to Cloudflare
elements.description:
You can use Cloudflare Tunnel to connect applications and services to Cloudflare’s network. Cloudflare Tunnel is an outbound-only daemon service that can run on nearly any host machine and proxies local traffic once validated from the Cloudflare network.

More information about this total flow can be found in our Private Network documentation.

pages.additional_description: Cloudflare Tunnel will run on a host locally in your network and make a persistent, outbound QUIC connection to Cloudflare.

pages.link_title: Create private network 'routes' in Cloudflare Tunnel
pages.additional_description: These entries determine which routes are available generally to WARP users in your Zero Trust tenant. It's okay to make these routes relatively wide, since you can add granular security control with Zero Trust policies.
While the Cloudflare Tunnel will advertise a relatively broad range, you can restrict network access by user identity, device posture, domain request, IP, port, protocol, and more.

elements.title: Agentless access to private web services
elements.description:
Cloudflare supports Zero Trust, identity-aware access to internal web, SSH, and VNC applications without the need to use a device client. This step will require an active DNS zone on Cloudflare in the same account in which you are building your Zero Trust policies.

Performing these tasks in this order makes sure your private asset is never accessible via the public Internet

elements.title: Connect user devices to Cloudflare
elements.description:
The WARP client encrypts designated traffic from a user's machine to the Cloudflare edge. It can run alongside other device VPNs so long as there are no route conflicts.

This setup uses a positive security model, meaning that only certain IP ranges or domains (local or external) are proxied through Cloudflare's network. Most admins test by downloading the client and authenticating in, but you can also set WARP via Managed deployments.

pages.additional_description: With device enrollment rules, you define which users in your organization can connect devices to your organization's Zero Trust instance.
We recommend manually deploying the client during your pilot and revisiting automated deployments during implementation.
This will allow WARP to build a Wireguard-based, encrypted tunnel on your device to route traffic to Cloudflare.

pages.link_title: Log your WARP client into your Zero Trust tenant
pages.additional_description: For initial testing, users should manually authenticate the client to their organization’s Cloudflare Zero Trust instance.

This will determine what traffic WARP does and does not proxy. If you intend to access applications remotely with a private IP address in a 10.0.0.0 range, ensure that is not excluded if running in exclude mode, and that it is included if deploying in include mode.
These policies allow Cloudflare to proxy requests to internal or private DNS infrastructure.

pages.link_title: Validate that Cloudflare is receiving your WARP traffic
pages.additional_description: Review your Gateway logs to make sure traffic is reaching the edge.
